instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SYS_DETECT_L: What is SYS_DETECT_L? For detection of the battery.
definitions.PCH_INTRUDER_L: What is PCH_INTRUDER_L? PCH_INTRUDER_L is a signal that tells the machine the case has been opened by an intruder when it is low, the _L means it is present when it is low. This signal should always be high in a Macbook since it doesn’t use intrusion detection. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PCH_INTVRMEN:
What is PCH_INTVRMEN? PCH_INTVRMEN is an Internal Voltage Regulator Enable: When pulled high, this signal enables
the internal 1.05 V regulators for the Suspend well in the PCH. This signal must
remain asserted for the VRMs to behave properly (no glitches allowed).
This signal must be pulled-up to VCCRTC on desktop platforms and may
optionally be pulled low on mobile platforms if using an external VR for the
VCCSUS rail.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_LSOC_RST_L: What is SMC_LSOC_RST_L? SMC_LSOC_RST_L is a signal that comes out of the trackpad on Macbook Airs that can reset the SMC.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power on
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B, that when it is powered off for a while, only powers on again when conected to the charger. With battery alone, it dosen´t power on at the firsts atempts  (even trigering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>), but then, after a few starts with the charger, it starts to work normaly.

Sometimes it only powers on again, disconnecting the battery.

I can´t see anything corroded, and i've already tried a know good battery.

J6950 w/o battery connected:
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> = 0V

J6950 with battery connected
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SYS_DETECT_L</SIGNAL> = 0V

The battery is recognized in macOS and is charging.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power on
threads.message:
Check if none of PCH's RTC signals has a critial level.
Must be all over 2.4V...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power on
threads.message:
Hi,

All 4 RTC signals are present

<SIGNAL>PCH_INTRUDER_L</SIGNAL> = 3V
<SIGNAL>PCH_INTVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.249V
<SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power on
threads.message: Check all <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> voltages, when the problem appears.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power on
threads.message:
Hi,

<CHIP>U5110</CHIP> pins voltages (battery only):
1 = 3.4V
3 = 3.4V
4 = 2.777V
5 =3.3V
6 =0.383V
7 = 3.4V
8 = 3.3V

After desconecting the keyboard, the mac powered on again, trigering <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> . Do you think it can be the KB, or maaybe it was it just another  coincidence?

Is there any way to test this for sure?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no power on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LSOC_RST_L</SIGNAL> must be always high.
Try another trackpad board.
